On the other hand it certainly will make a difference to Mastodon, and I hope it helps get the fediverse closer to critical mass.

And it's hilarious to see the graphs:

https://bitcoinhackers.org/@mastodonusercount/109244842600856469

@gerominowasteyute All of the code for Mastodon is available, and you can run your own, so if stuff isn't to your liking you can change it (or get someone else to do it for you).

It's as far from Twitter as you can get in that respect, since if Mastodon makes decisions people don't like, they can make their own copy *without* leaving.

(notice I'm on a different instance to you, and I intend on eventually setting up my own personal instance, neither of which is possible with Twitter)

object.content:
I find the obsessive "no algorithm, just chronological posts" obsession of some people quite naive.

Most people on Twitter don't once switch to chronological, and if they did they'd soon switch back, because if following more than a few people it's a nightmare.

There *will* eventually be clients and servers for ActivityPub with alternatives to chronological because a lot of people *will* prefer it.

That's fine. You have a choice of instance. You'll have a choice of algorithms.

#fediverse

object.content:
@bkeegan To H2, I suspect a lot of people here will find it traumatic how many things from Twitter will carry over with population *size*.

E.g. there will be instances w/ads. There will be instances with gamified interfaces. There will be non-chronological timelines on some instances (I'm looking to make one of those for myself, because I *want* to surface stuff from people I don't follow). And some will be closed source.

Upside: Federation makes most of this matter little; can choose it away.

object.content:
@bkeegan Also, those who did not experience the Eternal September on USENET may be woefully unprepared for just how much the growth of any social medium can transform the nature of discourse in that medium. The Fediverse might be better placed to weather it in that communities who dislike changes can ensconce themselves on instances much the same way refugees from USENET went to mailing lists and smaller forums, but without abandoning the network.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eternal_September

@jj_79 One missing bit: Does your instance subscribe to a *relay* that includes toots from @hello's instance? If yes, it shows in the federated timeline.

For smaller instances in particular, using a relay is a good way to improve discoverability.

E.g. see https://joinfediverse.wiki/index.php?title=Fediverse_relays

object.content:
@wajib If they favourite one of your posts, then that is a federated action. Their client (web interface or app) will post a Like activity to their "outbox". Their instance will then post that activity to your inbox, or the shared inbox of your instance.

This is how most federation works in Mastodon/ActivityPub. Likes/favourites are no different from other activities.

Following is only different in adding you to a list the remote instance will notify; still pushed by them.

contentMap.en:
@wajib If they favourite one of your posts, then that is a federated action. Their client (web interface or app) will post a Like activity to their "outbox". Their instance will then post that activity to your inbox, or the shared inbox of your instance.

This is how most federation works in Mastodon/ActivityPub. Likes/favourites are no different from other activities.

Following is only different in adding you to a list the remote instance will notify; still pushed by them.

object.content:
@cfiesler There's a short-term challenge there, to be sure, but today nobody struggles with the idea that you don't need to go to one specific site to get an e-mail address.

I also don't buy the notion that it will never serve the same broadcasting function -- that is *purely* a function of audience size. If there were 400m MAU on Mastodon, like on Twitter, it'd be used to broadcast just the same.

Doesn't mean Mastodon will "win" this instance. But I think in the long run 1/?

object.content:
@cfiesler federated social media will win because people are 1) experiencing wave after wave of failure modes of silos and getting used to exploring alternatives, and 2) federation lowers the threshold for starting something new and getting traction because the network isn't empty when you start and users may even be able to migrate their followers/following. So we will see endless proliferation of alternatives to Mastodon which can still communicate with Mastodon.

2/2

I keep making notes for a bunch of layered reality stories, btw., and his issue with them of lack of "real consequences" can be dealt with by inverting the relationship. That is, if you "dip down" into a simulated reality, there are no consequences because you can presumably exit. But if the entirety of you is in a simulation, actions can potentially not just end you, but end existence.

object.content:
@mjohnharrison Mastodon does link the posts, so we can see the whole thread. But one nice option: If you click on the globe symbol in the compose box, you can - if you choose - mark subsequent posts in a thread "unlisted" if you don't want people to wander into the middle. Then only the first one shows in your timeline.

The caveat is I often find interesting threads because of one of the posts in the middle, so not sure I'd recommend using that very much.

object.content:
@vbuterin @alexbfree @jerry

It really won't last; it's too trivially easy to circumvent. To me the question is rather whether there's anything that can be done to create a happy medium that discourages the worst excesses.

E.g. if a search can be provided that allows for user choice (opt in/out) that works well enough, can that discourage people from the effort involved in taking abusive steps to circumvent that choice?

attachment.name:
Article snipped from "The York Dispatch", August 08, 1931.

Air Liner Forced Down. Croydon-Paris Plane Makes Emergency Landing. London, Aug 8 -- Geat Britains largest air liner "Hannibal", carrying 18 passengers from Croydon to Paris made a forced landing today near Tonbridge. Noone was injured. The "Hannibal" left Croydon at 9:30 a.m. (4.30 a.m. EST) and was seen flying low near Tudely. After clearing the roof of a farmhouse, it came down in a field close to the Folkenstone-Dover railway.
Imperial Airways said the plane made a perfect landing. The passengers were taken to Lympne airdrome by motorcoach and a relief plane was sent from Croydon to pick them up and take them on to Paris.

The "Hannibal" is the largest and most luxurious passenger liner in the world. It made its maiden trip in June. The ship seats 38 people and has two large salons, one for smoking. It is equipped with four engines which enable it to cruise at 105 miles an hour. Despite the tremendous noise the interior of the cabins are almost silent, the plane being constructed along soundproof lines.

But at the same time I can see multiple trivial ways for bad actors to build their own search for abusive purposes that can't be reasonably stopped. To me that makes the question whether there are ways that makes more positive solutions the easier path.

Put another way: if a bad guy has to build their own, there won't be any opt-out or privacy controls.

object.content: @aredridel @analyticseqv Read "bad" and "good" more as "willing to follow consensus or not" in what I wrote. object.content:
@aredridel @analyticseqv Without consensus, resistance to search becomes even more futile, because then there's *nothing* to stop it.

So that means back to the point that the *best* we can do is to seek to make a middle ground that takes privacy concerns into account the "cheaper"/"easier" route to discourage the worse options.

Because search *will* come in one form or another, and the question is who shapes it (and has power over it).

object.content:

I'd happily see the fediverse split in two if that was the cost of better search and discovery.

But useful to reflect on which parts of Mastodon dogma matches ordinary users experiences w/Twitter. E. g. reverse chron timeline is a massive pain to me. People will build alternatives. Downside there is not algo but *lack of control* which we have here.

object.content: @bradpilcher @victoriadecapua @jon @PavelASamsonov Many options. Could do it standalone, using the API to obtain posts to filter and sort, so you'd get another page to go to, or could implement it in the core of Mastodon, and expose it in the standard UI. Also an option to implement a specialized. instance you can follow accounts on which would boost posts according to different algos. I expect we'll see people try out different options. I sure intend some experiments when I get time.

object.content: @shacker @ajroach42 @erindickins There's an open issue about this, and the opposition to it has been that it makes "faking" your timeline easier. Weak argument IMHO as it's trivial to fake now (run your own instance and mess with the database). Simple solution is to label migrated posts. Slightly harder, but far better, is to implement signed, securely timestamped posts. Refusing to migrate posts is just silly.

So that's a big yes from me anyway.

object.content:
@atomicpoet It's not about monetization but usability. Reverse chron is *already* too noisy for me here, while following 5 percent as many people as on Twitter. I will build my own algo ranking when I get a chance because reverse chron is horrible for me. And it's horrible for many others.

Twitter could have chosen to leave that to third party clients, but "monkeying" with the timeline is *necessary* for usability for most users.

And it will come here too, as a choice.

contentMap.en:
@atomicpoet It's not about monetization but usability. Reverse chron is *already* too noisy for me here, while following 5 percent as many people as on Twitter. I will build my own algo ranking when I get a chance because reverse chron is horrible for me. And it's horrible for many others.

Twitter could have chosen to leave that to third party clients, but "monkeying" with the timeline is *necessary* for usability for most users.

And it will come here too, as a choice.

object.content:
@atomicpoet I didn't at any point say mine is more important than yours, but the reverse is equally true. And of course you're free not to use it - odds are Mastodon core wouldn't accept it even if I offered it up (which I likely won't), and that's fine.

But the notion that an alternative to reverse chron wasn't needed doesn't mesh at all with how most people use social media. They had other options to monetize, but they did need it to keep people using Twitter at all.

contentMap.en:

object.content:
@atomicpoet That definition of need is not at all what I have in mind. What I mean by saying they needed it is that their engagement was low and that left them extremely vulnerable to competition had they not addressed it.

They could have monetized all they wanted, but their userbase would have stagnated and eventually declined, at which point monetization strategy would've been irrelevant.

The proportion of users for whom reverse chron is viable is *tiny*.

object.content:
@atomicpoet If they'd kept an open API then there'd have been plenty of interfaces that would monkey with the timeline, so we agree that might have been an option, though an unproven model in social media so I get why they didn't dare.

I'm not arguing that they couldn't have taken another approach to get an alternative to reverse chron.

I was arguing specifically that reverse chron being the only option makes for a service that massively lacks usability for typical users.

object.content:
@atomicpoet As a monetization strategy to largely replace ads it was, and is, entirely unproven at scale for a social network.

Wordpress does well, but the vast majority of Wordpress sites are not blogs, and even fewer have any kind of social features. They've found a lucrative market segment that is almost entirely unlike Twitters.

With respect to Digg, that was (and is) ad-driven, and Digg was *tiny* by modern standards.

object.content: Just realised that if I set up my own instance and have to do URL rewrites to make it "share" my main domain anyway, nothing also stops me from man-in-the-middle-ing my own instance so I can monkey with the timeline ordering all I want without patching the actual #mastodon installation by selectively redirecting API calls to a separate script. Makes it far easier to iterate, since I'll be able to turn it off just by flicking a load balancer rule.

object.content:
This part of the UK supreme court decision on #scotland is simply astounding:

"Its outcome would possess the authority, in a constitution and political culture founded upon democracy, of a democratic expression of the view of the Scottish electorate."

Basically, they're saying that *because it'd be hard to democratically justify ignoring the referendum*, the Scottish government can't unilaterally call one.

Way to admit the UK isn't a democratic country.

object.content:
@Labruunt @Velocity2222

Come here to see if this was posted. One of my favourites.

For those unaware of the backstory, the intention was for McNair to record the saxophone part of this track in space for the concert. After Challenger, Jarre considered canceling the whole concert but was convinced by McNair's friends to go through with it anyway and make it a tribute. The track is the last on the album Rendez-Vous, and is often listed as "Ron's Piece"

object.content:
@ben @blaine @dansinker @simon I'm in two minds now, actually after having looked at it more. The Mastodon API is clearly geared towards a client that can't hit remote servers, which makes sense because it needs to support the web UI. E.g. I can hit this URL to look me up:

https://mastodon.social/api/v1/accounts/lookup?acct=vidarh

But can also hit this URL to get a *mastodon.social* specific view of your account, Ben:

https://mastodon.social/api/v1/accounts/lookup?acct=ben@adida.net

Convenient for web clients, but extra burden for server writers.
